subparagraph.content: ‘Dynamic Mechanical Analysis glass transition temperature (DMA Tg)’ equal to or exceeding 505 K (232°C) and having a resin or pitch, not specified by 1C008 or 1C009(b), and not being a phenolic resin;

Metal or carbon-coated “fibrous or filamentary materials” (preforms) or “carbon fibre preforms”, not impregnated with resin or pitch, are specified by “fibrous or filamentary materials” in 1C010(a), 1C010(b) or 1C010(c).

subparagraph.leadIn: 1C010(e) does not apply to:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.leadIn: Epoxy resin “matrix” impregnated carbon “fibrous or filamentary materials” (prepregs) for the repair of “civil aircraft” structures or laminates, having all of the following:

subparagraph.content: An area not exceeding 1 m2;
A length not exceeding 2.5 m;
A width exceeding 15 mm;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Fully or partially resin-impregnated or pitch-impregnated mechanically chopped, milled or cut carbon “fibrous or filamentary materials” 25.0 mm or less in length when using a resin or pitch other than those specified by 1C008 or 1C009(b).

paragraph.continued: The ‘Dynamic Mechanical Analysis glass transition temperature (DMA Tg)’ for materials specified by 1C010(e) is determined using the method described in ASTM D 7028-07, or equivalent national standard, on a dry test specimen. In the case of thermoset materials, degree of cure of a dry test specimen shall be a minimum of 90% as defined by ASTM E 2160-04 or equivalent national standard. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

subsection.leadIn: Metals and compounds, as follows:
See ML8(c)(5)(b) for metal powders mixed with other substances to form a mixture formulated for military purposes. See also 1C111. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Metals in particle sizes of less than 60 μm whether spherical, atomized, spheroidal, flaked or ground, manufactured from material consisting of 99% or more of zirconium, magnesium and alloys of these: (L.N. 65 of 2004)
The natural content of hafnium in the zirconium (typically 2% to 7%) is counted with the zirconium.
The metals or alloys listed in 1C011(a) are controlled whether or not the metals or alloys are encapsulated in aluminium, magnesium, zirconium or beryllium. (L.N. 132 of 2001)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Boron or boron alloys, with a particle size of 60 μm or less, as follows:

subparagraph.content: Boron with a purity of 85% by weight or more;
Boron alloys with a boron content of 85% by weight or more;

paragraph.continued: The metals or alloys specified by 1C011(b) also refer to metals or alloys encapsulated in aluminium, magnesium, zirconium or beryllium. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Guanidine nitrate (CAS 506-93-4); (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Nitroguanidine (NQ) (CAS 556-88-7); (L.N. 132 of 2001)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Iodine pentafluoride (CAS 7783-66-6). (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subsection.leadIn: Materials as follows: (L.N. 132 of 2001)
These materials are typically used for nuclear heat sources. (L.N. 132 of 2001)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Plutonium in any form with a plutonium isotopic assay of plutonium-238 of more than 50% by weight;
1C012(a) does not control:

subparagraph.content: Shipments with a plutonium content of 1 g or less;
Shipments of 3 “effective grams” or less when contained in a sensing component in instruments. (L.N. 132 of 2001)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: “Previously separated” neptunium-237 in any form;
1C012(b) does not control shipments with a neptunium-237 content of 1 g or less.

subsection.leadIn: Materials and devices for reduced observables such as radar reflectivity, ultraviolet/infrared signatures and acoustic signatures, other than those controlled by 1C001, usable in ‘missiles’, ‘missile’ subsystems or unmanned aerial vehicles specified in 9A012 or 9A112(a); (L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.leadIn: 1C101 includes:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Structural materials and coatings specially designed for reduced radar reflectivity;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Coatings, including paints, specially designed for reduced or tailored reflectivity or emissivity in the microwave, infra red or ultra violet regions of the electromagnetic spectrum.

paragraph.content: 1C101 does not include coatings when specially used for the thermal control of satellites.

subsection.continued: In 1C101, ‘missiles’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.content: Resaturated pyrolized carbon-carbon materials designed for space launch vehicles controlled by 9A004 or sounding rockets controlled by 9A104;

subsection.leadIn: Graphite and ceramic materials, other than those controlled by 1C007, as follows: (L.N. 95 of 2006)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Fine grain graphites with a bulk density of 1.72 g/cm3 or greater, measured at 288 K (15°C), and having a grain size of 100 × 10-6m (100 μm) or less, usable for rocket nozzles and re-entry vehicle nose tips, which can be machined to any of the following products: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: Cylinders having a diameter of 120 mm or greater and a length of 50 mm or greater;
Blocks having a size of 120 mm × 120 mm × 50 mm or greater;

paragraph.continued: See also 0C004. (L.N. 95 of 2006)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Pyrolytic or fibrous reinforced graphites, usable for rocket nozzles and re-entry vehicle nose tips usable in “missiles”, space launch vehicles specified in 9A004 or sounding rockets specified in 9A104; (E.R. 6 of 2020)
See also 0C004. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Ceramic composite materials (dielectric constant less than 6 at any frequency from 100 MHz to 100 GHz) for use in radomes usable in “missiles”, space launch vehicles specified in 9A004 or sounding rockets specified in 9A104; (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Bulk machinable silicon-carbide reinforced unfired ceramic, usable for nose tips usable in “missiles”, space launch vehicles specified in 9A004 or sounding rockets specified in 9A104; (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Reinforced silicon-carbide ceramic composites, usable for nose tips, re-entry vehicles and nozzle flaps usable in “missiles”, space launch vehicles specified in 9A004 or sounding rockets specified in 9A104; (L.N. 254 of 2008; E.R. 6 of 2020)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: Bulk machinable ceramic composite materials consisting of an ‘Ultra High Temperature Ceramic (UHTC)’ matrix with a melting point equal to or greater than 3 000°C and reinforced with fibres or filaments, usable for missile components (such as nose-tips, re-entry vehicles, leading edges, jet vanes, control surfaces or rocket motor throat inserts) in “missiles”, space launch vehicles specified in 9A004, sounding rockets specified in 9A104 or ‘missiles’;
1C107(f) does not control ‘Ultra High Temperature Ceramic (UHTC)’ materials in non-composite form.

subparagraph.content: For the purposes of 1C107(f), ‘missile’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km.

subparagraph.leadIn: ‘Ultra High Temperature Ceramics (UHTCs)’ include:

subparagraph.content: Titanium diboride (TiB2);
Zirconium diboride (ZrB2);
Niobium diboride (NbB2);
Hafnium diboride (HfB2);
Tantalum diboride (TaB2);
Titanium carbide (TiC);
Zirconium carbide (ZrC);
Niobium carbide (NbC);
Hafnium carbide (HfC);
Tantalum carbide (TaC). (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Propellants and constituent chemicals for propellants, other than those specified in 1C011, as follows: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Propulsive substances:

subparagraph.content: Spherical or spheroidal aluminium powder, other than that specified in the Munitions List, in particle size of less than 200 μm and an aluminium content of 97% by weight or more, if at least 10% of the total weight is made up of particles of less than 63 μm, according to ISO 2591/1 (1988) or national equivalents;
A particle size of 63 μm (ISO R-565) corresponds to 250 mesh (Tyler) or 230 mesh (ASTM standard E-11). (L.N. 132 of 2001)

subparagraph.leadIn: Metal powders, other than those specified in the Munitions List, as follows:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.leadIn: Metal powders of zirconium, beryllium or magnesium, or alloys of these metals, if at least 90% of the total particles by particle volume or weight are made up of particles of less than 60 μm (determined by measurement techniques such as using a sieve, laser diffraction or optical scanning), whether spherical, atomized, spheroidal, flaked or ground, consisting 97% by weight or more of any of the following:

subparagraph.content: Zirconium;
Beryllium;
Magnesium;

subparagraph.continued: The natural content of hafnium in the zirconium (typically 2% to 7%) is counted with the zirconium.

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Metal powders of either boron or boron alloys with a boron content of 85% or more by weight, if at least 90% of the total particles by particle volume or weight are made up of particles of less than 60 μm (determined by measurement techniques such as using a sieve, laser diffraction or optical scanning), whether spherical, atomized, spheroidal, flaked or ground;

subparagraph.continued: 1C111(a)(2)(a) and 1C111(a)(2)(b) control powder mixtures with a multimodal particle distribution (e.g. mixtures of different grain sizes) if one or more modes are controlled. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.leadIn: Oxidizer substances usable in liquid propellant rocket engines as follows: (L.N. 254 of 2008)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Dinitrogen trioxide (CAS 10544-73-7);

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Nitrogen dioxide (CAS 10102-44-0)/dinitrogen tetroxide (CAS 10544-72-6);

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Dinitrogen pentoxide (CAS 10102-03-1);

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: Mixed Oxides of Nitrogen (MON);

Mixed Oxides of Nitrogen (MON) are solutions of Nitric Oxide (NO) in Dinitrogen Tetroxide/Nitrogen Dioxide (N2O4/NO2) that can be used in missile systems. There are a range of compositions that can be denoted as MONi or MONij, where i and j are integers representing the percentage of Nitric Oxide in the mixture (e.g. MON3 contains 3% Nitric Oxide, MON25 25% Nitric Oxide. An upper limit is MON40, 40% by weight).

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Inhibited Red Fuming Nitric Acid (IRFNA); (L.N. 65 of 2004)

subparagraph.name: f
subparagraph.leadIn: See the Munitions List and 1C238 for compounds composed of fluorine and one or more of other halogens, oxygen or nitrogen; (L.N. 65 of 2004)
Hydrazine derivatives as follows:
See also Munitions List. (L.N. 226 of 2009)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Trimethylhydrazine (CAS 1741-01-1); (L.N. 89 of 2013)

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Tetramethylhydrazine (CAS 6415-12-9); (L.N. 89 of 2013)

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: N,N-Diallylhydrazine (CAS 5164-11-4);

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: Allylhydrazine (CAS 7422-78-8); (L.N. 89 of 2013)

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: Ethylene dihydrazine (CAS 6068-98-0); (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.name: f
subparagraph.content: Monomethylhydrazine dinitrate;

subparagraph.name: g
subparagraph.content: Unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine nitrate;

subparagraph.name: h
subparagraph.content: Hydrazinium azide (CAS 14546-44-2); (L.N. 89 of 2013)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 1,1-Dimethylhydrazinium azide (CAS 227955-52-4)/1,2-Dimethylhydrazinium azide (CAS 299177-50-7); (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.name: j
subparagraph.content: Hydrazinium dinitrate (CAS 13464-98-7); (L.N. 226 of 2009)

subparagraph.name: k
l
subparagraph.content: 2-hydroxyethylhydrazine nitrate (HEHN);

subparagraph.name: m
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Hydrazinium perchlorate;

subparagraph.name: n
subparagraph.content: Hydrazinium diperchlorate (CAS 13812-39-0); (L.N. 161 of 2011)

subparagraph.name: o
subparagraph.content: Methylhydrazine nitrate (MHN) (CAS 29674-96-2);

subparagraph.name: p
subparagraph.content: 1,1-Diethylhydrazine nitrate (DEHN)/1,2-Diethylhydrazine nitrate (DEHN) (CAS 363453-17-2); and (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.name: q
subparagraph.content: 3,6-dihydrazino tetrazine nitrate (DHTN);
3,6-dihydrazino tetrazine nitrate (DHTN) is also referred to as 1,4-dihydrazine nitrate. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

subparagraph.leadIn: High energy density materials, other than that specified in the Munitions List, usable in ‘missiles’ or unmanned aerial vehicles specified in 9A012 or 9A112(a): (L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: Other high energy density fuels and fuel additives (e.g. cubane, ionic solutions, JP-10) having a volume-based energy density of 37.5 × 109 J/m3 or greater, measured at 20°C and one atmosphere (101.325 kPa) pressure;

1C111(a)(5)(b) does not control fossil refined fuels and biofuels produced from vegetables, including fuels for engines certified for use in civil aviation, unless specially formulated for ‘missiles’ or unmanned aerial vehicles specified in 9A012 or 9A112(a).

subparagraph.continued: In 1C111(a)(5) ‘missiles’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

subparagraph.leadIn: Hydrazine replacement fuels as follows:

subparagraph.name: a

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Polymeric substances:

subparagraph.content: Carboxy-terminated polybutadiene (including carboxyl-terminated polybutadiene) (CTPB);
Hydroxy-terminated polybutadiene (including hydroxyl-terminated polybutadiene) (HTPB) (CAS 69102-90-5), other than that specified in the Munitions List; (L.N. 89 of 2021)
Polybutadiene-acrylic acid (PBAA);
Polybutadiene-acrylic acid-acrylonitrile (PBAN) (CAS 25265-19-4/CAS 68891-50-9); (L.N. 89 of 2021)
Polytetrahydrofuran polyethylene glycol (TPEG);
Polytetrahydrofuran polyethylene glycol (TPEG) is a block co-polymer of poly 1,4-Butanediol (CAS 110-63-4) and polyethylene glycol (PEG) (CAS 25322-68-3). (L.N. 254 of 2008)
See the Munitions List for polyglycidyl nitrate (PGN or poly-GLYN) (CAS 27814-48-8); (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: Other propellant additives and agents:

subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for carboranes, decaboranes, pentaboranes and derivatives thereof; (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006)
Triethylene glycol dinitrate (TEGDN) (CAS 111-22-8);
2-Nitrodiphenylamine (CAS 119-75-5);
Diethylene glycol dinitrate (DEGDN) (CAS 693-21-0);

subparagraph.leadIn: Ferrocene derivatives as follows:

subparagraph.name: a
b
c
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for n-Propyl ferrocene (CAS 1273-92-3)/iso-propyl ferrocene (CAS 12126-81-7); (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.name: d
e
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Pentyl ferrocene (CAS 1274-00-6); (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.name: f
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Dicyclopentyl ferrocene (CAS 125861-17-8); (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.name: g
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Dicyclohexyl ferrocene;

subparagraph.name: h
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Diethyl ferrocene (CAS 1273-97-8); (L.N. 161 of 2011; L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Dipropyl ferrocene;

subparagraph.name: j
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Dibutyl ferrocene (CAS 1274-08-4); (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.name: k
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Dihexyl ferrocene (CAS 93894-59-8); (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.name: l
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for Acetyl ferrocene (CAS 1271-55-2)/1,1’-diacetyl ferrocene (CAS 1273-94-5); (L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.name: m
subparagraph.content: See the Munitions List for ferrocene carboxylic acids (CAS 1271-42-7)/1,1’-Ferrocenedicarboxylic acid (CAS 1293-87-4);

subparagraph.name: n
o
subparagraph.content: Other ferrocene derivatives usable as rocket propellant burning rate modifiers, other than those specified in the Munitions List; (L.N. 95 of 2006)
1C111(c)(6)(o) does not control ferrocene derivatives that contain a six carbon aromatic functional group attached to the ferrocene molecule. (L.N. 161 of 2011)
4,5-Diazidomethyl-2-methyl-1,2,3-triazole (iso-DAMTR), other than that specified in the Munitions List; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: ‘Gel propellants’, other than that specified in the Munitions List, specifically formulated for use in ‘missiles’;

subparagraph.content: For the purposes of 1C111(d), a ‘gel propellant’ is a fuel or oxidizer formulation using a gellant such as silicates, kaolin (clay), carbon or any polymeric gellant.
For the purposes of 1C111(d), ‘missile’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subsection.continued: For propellants and constituent chemicals for propellants not specified in 1C111, see the Munitions List. (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: Maraging steels, useable in ‘missiles’, that meet all of the following descriptions:
See also 1C216.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Having an ultimate tensile strength, measured at 293 K (20°C), equal to or greater than:

subparagraph.content: 0.9 GPa in the solution annealed stage; or
1.5 GPa in the precipitation hardened stage;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: In any of the following forms:

subparagraph.content: Sheet, plate or tubing with a wall or plate thickness equal to or less than 5.0 mm;
Tubular forms with a wall thickness equal to or less than 50 mm and having an inner diameter equal to or greater than 270 mm;

paragraph.leadIn: Maraging steels are iron alloy that is: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: Generally characterized by high nickel, very low carbon content and the use of substitutional elements or precipitates to produce strengthening and age-hardening of the alloy; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Subjected to heat treatment cycles to facilitate the martensitic transformation process (solution annealed stage) and subsequently age hardened (precipitation hardened stage).

paragraph.content: In 1C116, ‘missile’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: Materials for the fabrication of ‘missiles’ components as follows:

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.leadIn: Tungsten materials in solid form having all of the following:

subparagraph.leadIn: Any of the following material compositions:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Tungsten and alloys containing 97% by weight or more of tungsten;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Copper infiltrated tungsten containing 80% by weight or more of tungsten;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Silver infiltrated tungsten containing 80% by weight or more of tungsten; and

subparagraph.leadIn: Able to be machined to any of the following products:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Cylinders having a diameter of 120 mm or greater and a length of 50 mm or greater;

subparagraph.name: b
c
subparagraph.content: Blocks having a size of 120 mm by 120 mm by 50 mm or greater;

subsection.continued: In 1C117 ‘missiles’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km.

subsection.leadIn: Titanium-stabilized duplex stainless steel (Ti-DSS) having all of the following: (L.N. 65 of 2004)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: All of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: Containing 17.0 to 23.0 weight percent chromium and 4.5 to 7.0 weight percent nickel; and (E.R. 6 of 2020)
Having a titanium content of greater than 0.10 weight percent; and (L.N. 132 of 2001)

A ferritic-austenitic microstructure (also referred to as a two-phase microstructure) of which at least 10 percent is austenite by volume (according to ASTM E-1181-87 or national equivalents); and (L.N. 132 of 2001)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Any of the following forms:

subparagraph.content: Ingots or bars having a size of 100 mm or more in each dimension;
Sheets having a width of 600 mm or more and a thickness of 3 mm or less; or
Tubes having an outer diameter of 600 mm or more and a wall thickness of 3 mm or less; (L.N. 183 of 1999)

subsection.leadIn: Alloys, other than those controlled by 1C002(b)(3) or (b)(4), as follows: (L.N. 95 of 2006)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Aluminium alloys having both of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: ‘Capable of’ an ultimate tensile strength of 460 MPa or more at 293 K (20°C); and
In the form of tubes or cylindrical solid forms (including forgings) with an outside diameter of more than 75 mm;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Titanium alloys having both of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: ‘Capable of’ an ultimate tensile strength of 900 MPa or more at 293 K (20°C); and
In the form of tubes or cylindrical solid forms (including forgings) with an outside diameter of more than 75 mm;

subsection.continued: The phrase alloys ‘capable of’ encompasses alloys before or after heat treatment.

subsection.leadIn: ‘Fibrous or filamentary materials’ or prepregs, other than those controlled by 1C010(a), (b) or (e), as follows: (L.N. 95 of 2006)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Carbon or aramid ‘fibrous or filamentary materials’ having either of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: A “specific modulus” of 12.7 × 106 m or greater; or
A “specific tensile strength” of 23.5 × 104 m or greater;

paragraph.continued: 1C210(a) does not control aramid ‘fibrous or filamentary materials’ having 0.25 percent or more by weight of an ester based fibre surface modifier.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Glass ‘fibrous or filamentary materials’ having both of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: A “specific modulus” of 3.18 × 106 m or greater; and
A “specific tensile strength” of 7.62 × 104 m or greater;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Thermoset resin impregnated continuous “yarns”, “rovings”, “tows” or “tapes” with a width of 15 mm or less (prepregs), made from carbon or glass ‘fibrous or filamentary materials’ controlled by 1C210(a) or (b); (L.N. 95 of 2006)
The resin forms the matrix of the composite.

subsection.continued: In 1C210, ‘fibrous or filamentary materials’ is restricted to continuous “monofilaments”, “yarns”, “rovings”, “tows” or “tapes”.

subsection.leadIn: Maraging steel, other than that specified in 1C116, ‘capable of’ an ultimate tensile strength of 1 950 MPa or more, at 293 K (20°C); (L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 42 of 2017)
1C216 does not control forms in which all linear dimensions are 75 mm or less.
The phrase maraging steel ‘capable of’ encompasses maraging steel before or after heat treatment. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.content: Boron enriched in the boron-10 (10B) isotope to greater than its natural isotopic abundance, as follows: elemental boron, compounds, mixtures containing boron, manufactures thereof, waste or scrap of any of the foregoing;
In 1C225, mixtures containing boron include boron loaded materials.
The natural isotopic abundance of boron-10 is approximately 18.5 weight percent (20 atom percent). (L.N. 132 of 2001)

paragraph.name: a

subsection.content: Helium-3 (3He), mixtures containing helium-3, and products or devices containing any of the foregoing;
1C232 does not control a product or device containing less than 1 g of helium-3.

Lithium enriched in the lithium-6 (6Li) isotope to greater than its natural isotopic abundance, and products or devices containing enriched lithium, as follows: elemental lithium, alloys, compounds, mixtures containing lithium, manufactures thereof, waste or scrap of any of the foregoing;
1C233 does not control thermoluminescent dosimeters.
The natural isotopic abundance of lithium-6 is approximately 6.5 weight percent (7.5 atom percent). (L.N. 161 of 2011)

Zirconium with a hafnium content of less than 1 part hafnium to 500 parts zirconium by weight, as follows: metal, alloys containing more than 50% zirconium by weight, compounds, manufactures thereof, waste or scrap of any of the foregoing, other than those specified in 0A001(f); (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: ‘Genetic elements’ and ‘genetically-modified organisms’, as follows:

paragraph.leadIn: Any ‘genetically-modified organism’ that contains, or ‘genetic element’ that codes for, any of the following:

subparagraph.content: Any gene, genes, translated product or translated products, specific to any virus specified in 1C351(a) or 1C354(a); (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.leadIn: Any gene or genes specific to any bacterium specified in 1C351(c) or 1C354(b) or fungus specified in 1C351(e) or 1C354(c), and which is any of the following: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: Could ‘endow or enhance pathogenicity’;
Any “toxins” specified in 1C351(d) or “sub-units of toxins” for such “toxins”;

paragraph.content: ‘Genetically-modified organisms’ include organisms in which the nucleic acid sequences have been created or altered by deliberate molecular manipulation.

‘Genetic elements’ include inter alia chromosomes, genomes, plasmids, transposons, vectors and inactivated organisms containing recoverable nucleic acid fragments, whether genetically modified or unmodified, or chemically synthesized in whole or in part. For the purposes of the genetic elements control, nucleic acids from an inactivated organism, virus, or sample are considered recoverable if the inactivation and preparation of the material is intended or known to facilitate isolation, purification, amplification, detection, or identification of nucleic acids.

‘Endow or enhance pathogenicity’ is defined as when the insertion or integration of the nucleic acid sequence or sequences is/are likely to enable or increase a recipient organism’s ability to be used to deliberately cause disease or death. This might include alterations to, among other things: virulence, transmissibility, stability, route of infection, host range, reproducibility, ability to evade or suppress host immunity, resistance to medical countermeasures, or detectability.

1C353 does not include nucleic acid sequences of shiga toxin producing Escherichia coli of serogroups O26, O45, O103, O104, O111, O121, O145, O157, and other shiga toxin producing serogroups, other than those genetic elements coding for shiga toxin, or for its sub-units. (L.N. 85 of 2023)
1C353 does not control “vaccines”. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

section.content: Technology

subsection.content: “Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the “development” or “production” of equipment or materials controlled by 1A002, 1A003, 1A004, 1A005, 1A006(b), 1A007, 1B or 1C;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: “Technology” for the design or “production” of the following ceramic powders or non-“composite” ceramic materials: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.name: a
