paragraph.content: “Software” specially designed to enhance or release the performance of a camera or an imaging device to meet the characteristics of 6A203(a), 6A203(b) or 6A203(c) is specified in 6D203.
“Technology” in the form of keys or codes to enhance or release the performance of a camera or an imaging device to meet the characteristics of 6A203(a), 6A203(b) or 6A203(c) is specified in 6E203.

subsection.leadIn: 6A203(a), 6A203(b) and 6A203(c) does not control cameras or imaging devices that have hardware, “software” or “technology” constraints limiting their performance to less than that specified in 6A203(a), 6A203(b) and 6A203(c), if such cameras or imaging devices meet any of the following descriptions: (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.content: They need to be returned to the original manufacturer to make the enhancements or release the constraints;
They require “software” as specified in 6D203 to enhance or release the performance to meet the characteristics of 6A203;
They require “technology” in the form of keys or codes as specified in 6E203 to enhance or release the performance to meet the characteristics of 6A203.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Streak cameras, and specially designed components for such cameras, as follows:

subparagraph.content: Streak cameras with writing speeds greater than 0.5 mm/μs;
Electronic streak cameras capable of 50 ns or less time resolution;
Streak tubes for cameras specified in 6A203(a)(2);

Plug-ins specially designed for use with streak cameras that have modular structures and that enable the streak cameras to achieve the performance specifications in 6A203(a)(1) or 6A203(a)(2); (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Framing cameras, and specially designed components for such cameras, as follows:

subparagraph.content: Framing cameras with recording rates greater than 225 000 frames per second;
Framing cameras capable of 50 ns or less frame exposure time;

Plug-ins specially designed for use with framing cameras that have modular structures and that enable the framing cameras to achieve the performance specifications in 6A203(b)(1) or 6A203(b)(2); (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.continued: In 6A203(b), high speed single frame cameras can be used alone to produce a single image of a dynamic event, or several such cameras can be combined in a sequentially-triggered system to produce multiple images of an event.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: Solid-state cameras or electron tube cameras, and specially designed components for such cameras, as follows:

subparagraph.content: Solid-state cameras or electron tube cameras having a fast-image gating (shutter) time of 50 ns or less;
Electro-optical shuttering devices (Kerr or Pockels cells) having a fast-image gating (shutter) time of 50 ns or less;
Plug-ins specially designed for use with cameras that have modular structures and that enable the cameras to achieve the performance specifications in 6A203(c)(1); (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Radiation-hardened TV cameras, or lenses for such cameras, specially designed or rated as radiation-hardened to withstand a total radiation dose greater than 50 × 103 Gy (Silicon) (5 × 106 rad (Silicon)) without operational degradation;
The term Gy (Silicon) refers to the energy in Joules per kilogram absorbed by an unshielded silicon sample when exposed to ionizing radiation.

subsection.leadIn: “Lasers”, “laser” amplifiers and oscillators, other than those controlled by 0B001(g)(5), 0B001(h)(6) and 6A005, as follows: (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Argon ion “lasers” having both of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: Operating at wavelengths between 400 nm and 515 nm; and
An “average output power” greater than 40 W; (L.N. 65 of 2004)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Tunable pulsed single-mode dye laser oscillators having all of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: Operating at wavelengths between 300 nm and 800 nm;
An “average output power” greater than 1 W;
A repetition rate greater than 1 kHz; and
Pulse width less than 100 ns; (L.N. 65 of 2004)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: Tunable pulsed dye laser amplifiers and oscillators having all of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: Operating at wavelengths between 300 nm and 800 nm;
An “average output power” greater than 30 W;
A repetition rate greater than 1 kHz; and
Pulse width less than 100 ns;

paragraph.continued: 6A205(c) does not control single mode oscillators. (L.N. 65 of 2004)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: Pulsed carbon dioxide (CO2) “lasers” having all of the following characteristics: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: Operating at wavelengths between 9 000 nm and 11 000 nm;
A repetition rate greater than 250 Hz;
Pulse width less than 200 ns; (L.N. 65 of 2004)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Para-hydrogen Raman shifters designed to operate at 16 μm output wavelength and at a repetition rate greater than 250 Hz; (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: Neodymium-doped (other than glass) “lasers” with an output wavelength between 1 000 nm and 1 100 nm, having any of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.leadIn: Pulse-excited and Q-switched with a pulse duration equal to or more than 1 ns, and having:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: A single-transverse mode output with an “average output power” greater than 40 W; or

subparagraph.name: b

subparagraph.content: Incorporating frequency doubling to give an output wavelength between 500 nm and 550 nm with an “average output power” greater than 40 W; (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: Pulsed carbon monoxide (CO) “lasers”, other than those specified in 6A005(d)(2), that meet all of the following descriptions: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: Operating at wavelengths between 5 000 nm and 6 000 nm;
A repetition rate greater than 250 Hz;
An “average output power” greater than 200 W;
Pulse width of less than 200 ns; (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.continued: For copper vapour lasers, see 6A005(b). (L.N. 226 of 2009)

subsection.content: Velocity interferometers for measuring velocities exceeding 1 km/s during time intervals of less than 10 microseconds;

6A225 includes velocity interferometers such as VISARs (Velocity Interferometer Systems for Any Reflector), DLIs (Doppler Laser Interferometers) and PDV (Photonic Doppler Velocimeters) also known as Het-V (Heterodyne Velocimeters). (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: Pressure sensors, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Shock pressure gauges capable of measuring pressures greater than 10 GPa, including gauges made with manganin, ytterbium, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)/polyvinyl difluoride (PVF2); or (L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Quartz pressure transducers for pressures greater than 10 GPa; (L.N. 132 of 2001; L.N. 42 of 2017)

section.name: s0
section.content: Test, Inspection and Production Equipment

subsection.content: Masks and reticles, specially designed for optical sensors specified in 6A002(a)(1)(b) or 6A002(a)(1)(d);

subsection.leadIn: Optical equipment, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Equipment for measuring absolute reflectance to an “accuracy” of equal to or less (better) than 0.1% of the reflectance value; (L.N. 89 of 2021; L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Equipment other than optical surface scattering measurement equipment, having an unobscured aperture of more than 10 cm, specially designed for the non-contact optical measurement of a non-planar optical surface figure (profile) to an “accuracy” of 2 nm or less (better) against the required profile;

subsection.continued: 6B004 does not control microscopes.

subsection.content: Equipment to produce, align and calibrate land-based gravity meters with a static “accuracy” of less (better) than 0.1 mGal;
Pulse radar cross-section measurement systems having transmit pulse widths of 100 ns or less and specially designed components therefor;
See also 6B108.
Systems, other than those controlled by 6B008, specially designed for radar cross-section measurement usable for ‘missiles’ and their subsystems; (L.N. 254 of 2008)
In 6B108, ‘missiles’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

section.name: s0
section.content: Materials

subsection.leadIn: Optical sensor materials, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Elemental tellurium (Te) of purity levels of 99.9995% or more;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Single crystals (including epitaxial wafers) of any of the following:

subparagraph.content: Cadmium zinc telluride (CdZnTe) with zinc content of less than 6% by ‘mole fraction’; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
Cadmium telluride (CdTe) of any purity level; or

paragraph.continued: ‘Mole fraction’ is defined as the ratio of moles of ZnTe to the sum of the moles of CdTe and ZnTe present in the crystal. (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: Optical materials, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Zinc selenide (ZnSe) and zinc sulphide (ZnS) “substrate blanks” produced by the chemical vapour deposition process and having any of the following: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.content: A volume greater than 100 cm3; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Electro-optic materials and non-linear optical materials, as follows: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.content: Potassium titanyl arsenate (KTA) (CAS 59400-80-5);
Silver gallium selenide (AgGaSe2, also known as AGSE) (CAS 12002-67-4); (L.N. 42 of 2017)
Thallium arsenic selenide (Tl3AsSe3, also known as TAS) (CAS 16142-89-5); (L.N. 161 of 2011)
Zinc germanium phosphide (ZnGeP2, also known as ZGP, zinc germanium biphosphide or zinc germanium diphosphide); (L.N. 42 of 2017)
Gallium selenide (GaSe) (CAS 12024-11-2); (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: Non-linear optical materials, other than those specified in 6C004(b), that meet any of the following descriptions:

subparagraph.leadIn: Having all of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: Response time of less than 1 ms;
Second order non-linear susceptibility (χ(2), chi 2) of 3.3 × 10–11 m/V or more; (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.leadIn: Glass, including fused silica, phosphate glass, fluorophosphate glass, zirconium fluoride (ZrF4) (CAS 7783-64-4) and hafnium fluoride (HfF4) (CAS 13709-52-9), having all of the following: (L.N. 161 of 2011)

subparagraph.content: A hydroxyl ion (OH-) concentration of less than 5 ppm;
Integrated metallic purity levels of less than 1 ppm; and
High homogeneity (index of refraction variance) less than 5 × 10-6;

paragraph.name: f

subsection.leadIn: “Laser” materials, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Synthetic crystalline “laser” host material in unfinished form, as follows:

subparagraph.content: Titanium doped sapphire;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Rare-earth-metal doped double-clad fibres that have:

subparagraph.leadIn: A nominal “laser” wavelength of 975 nm to 1 150 nm, with: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: An average core diameter that is equal to or greater than 25 μm; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: A core ‘Numerical Aperture’ (‘NA’) that is less than 0.065; or

subparagraph.continued: 6C005(b)(1) does not control double-clad fibres that have an inner glass cladding diameter exceeding 150 μm but not exceeding 300 μm.

subparagraph.leadIn: A nominal “laser” wavelength exceeding 1 530 nm, with: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: An average core diameter that is equal to or greater than 20 μm; and

subparagraph.name: b

paragraph.continued: 6C005(b) includes fibres assembled with end caps. (L.N. 6 of 2025)
paragraph.leadIn: For the purposes of 6C005(b), core ‘Numerical Aperture’ (‘NA’) is measured at the emission wavelengths of the fibre. (L.N. 6 of 2025)

section.name: s0
section.content: Software

subsection.content: “Software” specially designed for the “development” or “production” of equipment controlled by 6A004, 6A005, 6A008 or 6B008;
“Software” specially designed for the “use” of equipment controlled by 6A002(b), 6A008 or 6B008;

subsection.leadIn: Other “software”, as follows:

subparagraph.content: “Source code” for the “real time processing” of acoustic data for passive reception using towed hydrophone arrays;
“Software” specially designed for acoustic beam forming for the “real time processing” of acoustic data for passive reception using bottom or bay cable systems; (L.N. 183 of 1999)
“Source code” for the “real time processing” of acoustic data for passive reception using bottom or bay cable systems; (L.N. 183 of 1999)

subparagraph.leadIn: “Software” or “source code”, specially designed for all of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: “Real time processing” of acoustic data from sonar systems specified by 6A001(a)(1)(e);

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Automatically detecting, classifying and determining the location of divers or swimmers;

subparagraph.continued: For diver detection “software” or “source code”, specially designed or modified for military use, see the Munitions List. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Deleted; (L.N. 226 of 2009)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: “Software” designed or modified for cameras incorporating “focal plane arrays” specified in 6A002(a)(3)(f) and designed or modified to remove a frame rate restriction and allow the camera to exceed the frame rate specified in 6A003(b)(4) Note 3(a); (L.N. 226 of 2009)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: “Software” specially designed to maintain the alignment and phasing of segmented mirror systems that consist of mirror segments with a diameter or major axis length that is equal to or greater than 1 m; (L.N. 226 of 2009; L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Deleted; (L.N. 226 of 2009)

subparagraph.content: “Software” specially designed for magnetic and electric field “compensation systems” for magnetic sensors designed to operate on mobile platforms; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
“Software” specially designed for magnetic and electric field anomaly detection on mobile platforms; (L.N. 95 of 2006)
“Software” specially designed for “real time processing” of electromagnetic data using underwater electromagnetic receivers specified by 6A006(e); (L.N. 161 of 2011)
“Source code” for “real time processing” of electromagnetic data using underwater electromagnetic receivers specified by 6A006(e); (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: “Software” specially designed to correct motional influences of gravity meters or gravity gradiometers;

subparagraph.content: Air Traffic Control (ATC) “software” designed to be hosted on general purpose computers located at Air Traffic Control centres and capable of accepting radar target data from more than four primary radars; (L.N. 161 of 2011; L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.leadIn: “Software” for the design or “production” of radomes which:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Are specially designed to protect the electronically scanned array antennae controlled by 6A008(e); and (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: ‘Average side lobe level’ in 6D003(h)(2)(b) is measured over the entire array excluding the angular extent of the main beam and the first two side lobes on either side of the main beam.

subsection.content: “Software” which processes post-flight, recorded data, enabling determination of vehicle position throughout its flight path, specially designed or modified for ‘missiles’; (L.N. 132 of 2001; L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006)
In 6D103, ‘missiles’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km. (L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 85 of 2023)

section.name: s0
section.content: Technology

subsection.content: “Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the “development” of equipment, materials or “software” controlled by 6A, 6B, 6C or 6D;
“Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the “production” of equipment or materials controlled by 6A, 6B or 6C;

subsection.leadIn: Other “technology”, as follows:

subparagraph.content: Optical surface coating and treatment “technology” “required” to achieve an ‘optical thickness’ uniformity of 99.5% or better for optical coatings 500 mm or more in diameter or major axis length and with a total loss (absorption and scatter) of less than 5 × 10-3; (L.N. 161 of 2011)
See also 2E003(f).
‘Optical thickness’ is the mathematical product of the index of refraction and the physical thickness of the coating. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

subparagraph.leadIn: “Technology” for the fabrication of optics using single point diamond turning techniques to produce surface finish “accuracies” of less (better) than 10 nm rms on non-planar surfaces exceeding 0.5 m2; (L.N. 85 of 2023; L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: “Technology” “required” for the “development”, “production” or “use” of specially designed diagnostic instruments or targets in test facilities for “SHPL” testing or testing or evaluation of materials irradiated by “SHPL” beams;

subsection.content: 6E101 only controls “technology” for equipment controlled by 6A002, 6A007 and 6A008 when it is designed for airborne applications and is usable in “missiles”. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: “Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the “use” of equipment specified in 6A003, 6A005(a)(2), 6A005(b)(2), 6A005(b)(3), 6A005(b)(4), 6A005(b)(6), 6A005(c)(2), 6A005(d)(3)(c), 6A005(d)(4)(c), 6A202, 6A203, 6A205, 6A225 or 6A226;

paragraph.content: 6E201 only controls “technology” for cameras specified in 6A003 if the cameras are also specified in any of the control parameters of 6A203.
6E201 only controls “technology” for “lasers” in 6A005(b)(6) that are neodymium-doped and specified in any of the control parameters of 6A205(f). (L.N. 89 of 2021)

section.name: s0
section.content: Systems, Equipment and Components
For automatic pilots for submersible vehicles, see Category 8. (L.N. 6 of 2025)
For radar, see Category 6. (L.N. 65 of 2004)

subsection.leadIn: Accelerometers as follows and specially designed components for accelerometers:
For angular or rotational accelerometers, see 7A001(b). See also 7A101.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Linear accelerometers having any of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.leadIn: Specified to function at linear acceleration levels less than or equal to 15 g and having:

subparagraph.name: a
b

subparagraph.leadIn: Specified to function at linear acceleration levels exceeding 15 g but less than or equal to 100 g and having all of the following: (L.N. 161 of 2011)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: A “bias” “repeatability” of less (better) than 1 250 micro g over a period of one year; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: A “scale factor” “repeatability” of less (better) than 1 250 ppm over a period of one year; (L.N. 42 of 2017)
Designed for use in inertial navigation or guidance systems and specified to function at linear acceleration levels exceeding 100 g; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.continued: 7A001(a)(1) and 7A001(a)(2) do not apply to accelerometers limited to measurement of only vibration or shock. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Angular or rotational accelerometers, specified to function at linear acceleration levels exceeding 100 g;

subsection.leadIn: Gyros or angular rate sensors, having any of the following characteristics and specially designed components for gyros or angular rate sensors:
See also 7A102. For angular or rotational accelerometers, see 7A001(b).

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Specified to function at linear acceleration levels less than or equal to 100 g and having any of the following:

subparagraph.leadIn: An angular rate range of less than 500 degrees per second and having any of the following: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: An “angle random walk” of less (better) than or equal to 0.0035 degree per square root hour;
7A002(a)(1)(b) does not control “spinning mass gyros”.

subparagraph.leadIn: An angular rate range greater than or equal to 500 degrees per second and having any of the following: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: An “angle random walk” of less (better) than or equal to 0.1 degree per square root hour;
7A002(a)(2)(b) does not control “spinning mass gyros”. (L.N. 161 of 2011; L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: b

subsection.leadIn: ‘Inertial measurement equipment or systems’ that meet any of the following descriptions:
See also 7A103.

7A003 does not apply to ‘inertial measurement equipment or systems’ which are certified for use on “civil aircraft” by civil aviation authorities of one or more “Participating States”. (L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.leadIn: ‘Inertial measurement equipment or systems’ incorporate accelerometers or gyroscopes to measure changes in velocity and orientation in order to determine or maintain heading or position without requiring an external reference once aligned. ‘Inertial measurement equipment or systems’ include the following:
—Attitude and Heading Reference Systems (AHRSs);
—Gyrocompasses;
—Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs);
—Inertial Navigation Systems (INSs);
—Inertial Reference Systems (IRSs);
—Inertial Reference Units (IRUs).
‘Positional aiding references’ independently provide position, and include all of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: “Satellite navigation system”;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: “Data-Based Referenced Navigation” (“DBRN”). (L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Designed for “aircraft”, land vehicles or vessels, providing position without the use of ‘positional aiding references’, and having any of the following “accuracies” subsequent to normal alignment: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: 0.8 nautical miles per hour (nm/hr) “Circular Error Probable” (“CEP”) rate or less (better);
Total drift of 1 nautical mile “CEP” or less (better) in a 24-hour period;

paragraph.continued: The performance parameters in 7A003(a)(1), 7A003(a)(2) and 7A003(a)(3) typically apply to ‘inertial measurement equipment or systems’ designed for “aircraft”, vehicles and vessels, respectively. These parameters result from the utilization of specialized non-‘positional aiding references’ (e.g. altimeter, odometer, velocity log). As a consequence, the specified performance values cannot be readily converted between these parameters. Equipment designed for multiple platforms are evaluated against each applicable entry 7A003(a)(1), 7A003(a)(2) or 7A003(a)(3). (L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Designed for “aircraft”, land vehicles or vessels, with an embedded ‘positional aiding reference’ and providing position after loss of all ‘positional aiding references’ for a period of up to 4 minutes, having an “accuracy” of less (better) than 10 metres “CEP”;

7A003(b) refers to systems in which ‘inertial measurement equipment or systems’ and other independent ‘positional aiding references’ are built into a single unit (i.e. embedded) in order to achieve improved performance.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: Designed for “aircraft”, land vehicles or vessels, providing heading or True North determination and meeting any of the following descriptions:

subparagraph.content: Having a maximum operating angular rate less (lower) than 500 deg/s and a heading “accuracy” without the use of ‘positional aiding references’ equal to or less (better) than 0.07 deg sec(Lat) (equivalent to 6 arc minutes rms at 45 degrees latitude);

Having a maximum operating angular rate equal to or greater (higher) than 500 deg/s and a heading “accuracy” without the use of ‘positional aiding references’ equal to or less (better) than 0.2 deg sec(Lat) (equivalent to 17 arc minutes rms at 45 degrees latitude);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: Providing acceleration measurements or angular rate measurements, in more than one dimension, and meeting any of the following descriptions:

subparagraph.content: Having performance specified in 7A001 or 7A002 along any axis, without the use of any aiding references;

content.content: 7A003(d)(2) does not control ‘inertial measurement equipment or systems’ that contain “spinning mass gyros” as the only type of gyro.

subsection.leadIn: ‘Star trackers’ and their components, as follows:
See also 7A104. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ‘Star trackers’ with a specified azimuth “accuracy” of equal to or less (better) than 20 seconds of arc throughout the specified lifetime of the equipment; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Components specially designed for equipment specified in 7A004(a) as follows:

subparagraph.content: Optical heads or baffles;
Data processing units;

subsection.continued: ‘Star trackers’ are also referred to as stellar attitude sensors or gyro-astro compasses.

subsection.leadIn: “Satellite navigation system” receiving equipment having any of the following and specially designed components therefor: (L.N. 85 of 2023)
See also 7A105. For equipment specially designed for military use, see ML11.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Employing a decryption algorithm specially designed or modified for government use to access the ranging code for position and time;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Employing ‘adaptive antenna systems’;

7A005(b) does not apply to “satellite navigation system” receiving equipment that only uses components designed to filter, switch, or combine signals from multiple omni-directional antennae that do not implement adaptive antenna techniques. (L.N. 85 of 2023)
For the purposes of 7A005(b) ‘adaptive antenna systems’ dynamically generate one or more spatial nulls in an antenna array pattern by signal processing in the time domain or frequency domain.

subsection.leadIn: Airborne altimeters operating at frequencies other than 4.2 to 4.4 GHz inclusive, having any of the following characteristics:
See also 7A106.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “Power management”; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Using phase shift key modulation;

subsection.content: Underwater sonar navigation systems using Doppler-velocity or correlation-velocity logs integrated with a heading source and having a positioning “accuracy” of equal to or less (better) than 3% of distance travelled “Circular Error Probable” (“CEP”) and specially designed components for those systems; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
7A008 does not include systems specially designed for installation on surface vessels or systems requiring acoustic beacons or buoys to provide positioning data.
See 6A001(a) for acoustic systems, and 6A001(b) for correlation-velocity and Doppler-velocity sonar log equipment. See 8A002 for other marine systems.

subsection.leadIn: Linear accelerometers, other than those specified in 7A001, designed for use in inertial navigation systems or in guidance systems of all types, usable in ‘missiles’, having all of the following characteristics, and specially designed components for those linear accelerometers: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: A “bias” “repeatability” of less (better) than 1 250 micro g;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: A “scale factor” “repeatability” of less (better) than 1 250 ppm;

subsection.continued: 7A101 does not control accelerometers specially designed and developed as MWD (Measurement While Drilling) Sensors for use in downhole well service operations. (L.N. 161 of 2011; L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.content: In 7A101, the term ‘missile’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km.
In 7A101, the measurement of “bias” and “scale factor” refers to a one sigma standard deviation with respect to a fixed calibration over a period of one year.

subsection.leadIn: All types of gyros, other than those controlled by 7A002, usable in ‘missiles’, with a rated “drift rate” ‘stability’ of less than 0.5° (1 sigma or rms) per hour in a 1 g environment and specially designed components therefor; (L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.content: In 7A102, ‘missiles’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km.

In 7A102, ‘stability’ means a measure of the ability of a specific mechanism or performance coefficient to remain invariant when continuously exposed to a fixed operating condition (IEEE STD 528-2001 paragraph 2.247). (L.N. 254 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: Instrumentation, navigation equipment and systems, other than those controlled by 7A003, as follows; and specially designed components therefor:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: ‘Inertial measurement equipment or systems’, using accelerometers or gyros as follows: (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.content: Accelerometers specified in 7A001(a)(3), 7A001(b) or 7A101 or gyros specified in 7A002 or 7A102; or
7A103(a)(1) does not control equipment containing accelerometers controlled by 7A001(a)(3) that are designed to measure vibration or shock. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

Accelerometers specified in 7A001(a)(1) or 7A001(a)(2) designed for use in inertial navigation systems or in guidance systems of all types, and usable in ‘missiles’; (L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 89 of 2021)

7A103(a)(2) does not include equipment containing accelerometers specified in 7A001(a)(1) or 7A001(a)(2) where such accelerometers are specially designed and developed as MWD (Measurement While Drilling) Sensors for use in downhole well service operations. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.continued: ‘Inertial measurement equipment or systems’ controlled by 7A103(a) incorporate accelerometers or gyros to measure changes in velocity and orientation in order to determine or maintain heading or position without requiring an external reference once aligned. (L.N. 89 of 2021)
‘Inertial measurement equipment or systems’ in 7A103(a) include:

—Attitude and Heading Reference Systems (AHRSs)
—Gyrocompasses
—Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs)
—Inertial Navigation Systems (INSs)
—Inertial Reference Systems (IRSs)
—Inertial Reference Units (IRUs) (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: ‘Integrated navigation systems’, designed or modified for ‘missiles’ and capable of providing a navigational accuracy of 200 m ‘CEP’ or less; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.leadIn: An ‘integrated navigation system’ typically incorporates the following components: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: One or more external sensors used to update the position or velocity or both, either periodically or continuously throughout the flight (e.g. satellite navigation receiver, radar altimeter, or Doppler radar); and

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Integration hardware and software. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

In 7A103(c), ‘CEP’ (Circular Error Probable or Circle of Equal Probability) is a measure of accuracy, defined as the radius of the circle inside of which there is a 50% probability of being located. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: Three axis magnetic heading sensors, designed or modified to be integrated with flight control and navigation systems, other than those specified in 6A006, having all of the following characteristics, and specially designed components for those sensors: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.content: Internal tilt compensation in pitch (+90 degrees) and roll (+180 degrees) axes;

paragraph.continued: Flight control and navigation systems in 7A103(d) include gyrostabilizers, automatic pilots and inertial navigation systems. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

subsection.continued: In 7A103, ‘missiles’ means complete rocket systems and unmanned aerial vehicle systems capable of a range exceeding 300 km. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

subsection.content: Gyro-astro compasses and other devices, other than those controlled by 7A004, which derive position or orientation by means of automatically tracking celestial bodies or satellites and specially designed components therefor;

subsection.leadIn: Receiving equipment for ‘navigation satellite systems’, other than those specified in 7A005, having any of the following characteristics, and specially designed components therefor: (L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Designed or modified for use in space launch vehicles controlled by 9A004, sounding rockets controlled by 9A104 or unmanned aerial vehicles controlled by 9A012 or 9A112(a); (L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Designed or modified for airborne applications and having any of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.content: Capable of providing navigation information at speeds in excess of 600 m/s; (L.N. 95 of 2006)
Employing decryption, designed or modified for military or governmental services, to gain access to a ‘navigation satellite system’ secured signal/data; or (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.continued: 7A105(b)(2) and 7A105(b)(3) do not control equipment designed for commercial, civil or ‘Safety of Life’ (e.g. data integrity, flight safety) ‘navigation satellite system’ services. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subsection.continued: In 7A105, ‘navigation satellite system’ includes Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS; e.g. GPS, GLONASS, Galileo or BeiDou) and Regional Navigation Satellite Systems (RNSS; e.g. NavIC, QZSS). (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Passive sensors for determining bearing to specific electromagnetic source (direction finding equipment) or terrain characteristics, designed or modified for use in space launch vehicles controlled by 9A004 or sounding rockets controlled by 9A104; (L.N. 183 of 1999; L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006)
Equipment controlled by 7A105, 7A106 and 7A115 includes the following:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Terrain contour mapping equipment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Scene mapping and correlation (both digital and analogue) equipment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Doppler navigation radar equipment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Passive interferometer equipment;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Imaging sensor equipment (both active and passive). (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Flight control systems and servo valves, as follows; designed or modified for use in space launch vehicles controlled by 9A004 or sounding rockets controlled by 9A104 or “missiles”: (L.N. 183 of 1999; L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Pneumatic, hydraulic, mechanical, electro-optical, or electro-mechanical flight control systems (including fly-by-wire and fly-by-light systems); (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Attitude control equipment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Flight control servo valves designed or modified for the systems controlled by 7A116(a) or 7A116(b) and designed or modified to operate in a vibration environment greater than 10 g rms between 20 Hz and 2 kHz; (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.continued: For conversion of manned aircraft to operate as “missiles”, 7A116 includes the systems, equipment and valves designed or modified to enable operation of manned aircraft as unmanned aerial vehicles. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subsection.content: “Guidance sets”, usable in “missiles”, capable of achieving system accuracy of 3.33% or less of the range (e.g. a ‘CEP’ of 10 km or less at a range of 300 km); (E.R. 6 of 2020; L.N. 85 of 2023)

In 7A117, ‘CEP’ (Circular Error Probable or Circle of Equal Probability) is a measure of accuracy, defined as the radius of the circle centred at the target, at a specific range, in which 50% of the payloads impact. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

section.name: s0
section.content: Test, Inspection snd Production Equipment

subsection.leadIn: Test, calibration or alignment equipment specially designed for equipment controlled by 7A;
7B001 does not control test, calibration or alignment equipment for ‘Maintenance Level I’ or ‘Maintenance Level II’.

paragraph.content: ‘Maintenance Level I’ (L.N. 85 of 2023)

The failure of an inertial navigation unit is detected on the “aircraft” by indications from the control and display unit (CDU) or by the status message from the corresponding sub-system. By following the manufacturer’s manual, the cause of the failure may be localized at the level of the malfunctioning line replaceable unit (LRU). The operator then removes the LRU and replaces it with a spare. (E.R. 6 of 2020)
‘Maintenance Level II’ (L.N. 85 of 2023)

The defective LRU is sent to the maintenance workshop (the manufacturer’s or that of the operator responsible for level II maintenance). At the maintenance workshop, the malfunctioning LRU is tested by various appropriate means to verify and localize the defective shop replaceable assembly (SRA) module responsible for the failure. This SRA is removed and replaced by an operative spare. The defective SRA (or possibly the complete LRU) is then shipped to the manufacturer. ‘Maintenance Level II’ does not include the disassembly or repair of specified accelerometers or gyro sensors. (L.N. 161 of 2011; E.R. 6 of 2020)

subsection.leadIn: Equipment, as follows, specially designed to characterize mirrors for ring “laser” gyros:
See also 7B102.

paragraph.content: Profilometers having a measurement “accuracy” of 0.5 nm (5 angstrom) or less (better); (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: Equipment specially designed for the “production” of equipment specified in 7A;
7B003 includes:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Gyro tuning test stations;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Gyro dynamic balance stations;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Gyro run-in/motor test stations;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Gyro evacuation and fill stations;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Centrifuge fixtures for gyro bearings;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: Accelerometer axis align stations; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: Fibre optic gyro coil winding machines. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

subsection.content: Reflectometers specially designed to characterize mirrors, for “laser” gyros, having a measurement accuracy of 50 ppm or less (better);

subsection.leadIn: “Production facilities” and “production equipment” as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “Production facilities” specially designed for equipment controlled by 7A117;

paragraph.name: b

section.name: s0
section.content: Materials None

section.name: s0
section.content: Software

subsection.content: “Software” specially designed or modified for the “development” or “production” of equipment controlled by 7A or 7B;
7D002 does not apply to “source code” for the operation or maintenance of gimballed ‘AHRS’.

‘AHRS’ generally differs from Inertial Navigation Systems (INS) in that an ‘AHRS’ provides attitude and heading information and normally does not provide the acceleration, velocity and position information associated with an INS.

subsection.leadIn: Other “software”, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “Software” specially designed or modified to improve the operational performance or reduce the navigational error of systems to the levels specified in 7A003, 7A004 or 7A008; (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: “Source code” for hybrid integrated systems which improves the operational performance or reduces the navigational error of systems to the levels specified in 7A003 or 7A008 by continuously combining heading data with any of the following: (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 254 of 2008)

subparagraph.content: Doppler radar or sonar velocity data; (L.N. 254 of 2008)
“Satellite navigation system” references data; or (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Computer-aided-design (CAD) “software” specially designed for the “development” of “active flight control systems”, helicopter multi-axis fly-by-wire or fly-by-light controllers or helicopter “circulation-controlled anti-torque or circulation-controlled direction control systems” whose “technology” is controlled by 7E004(b)(1), 7E004(b)(3), 7E004(b)(4), 7E004(b)(5), 7E004(b)(7), 7E004(b)(8), 7E004(c)(1) or 7E004(c)(2);

subsection.leadIn: “Source code” incorporating “development” “technology” controlled by 7E004(a)(2), 7E004(a)(3), 7E004(a)(5), 7E004(a)(6) or 7E004(b), for any of the following:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Digital flight management systems for “total control of flight”;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Integrated propulsion and flight control systems;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: “Fly-by-wire systems” or “fly-by-light systems”;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Fault-tolerant or self-reconfiguring “active flight control systems”;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Not used;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: Air data systems based on surface static data;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: 3-dimensional displays;

subsection.continued: 7D004 does not control “source code” associated with common computer elements and utilities (e.g. input signal acquisition, output signal transmission, computer “program” and data loading, built-in test, task scheduling mechanisms) not providing a specific flight control system function. (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subsection.content: “Software” specially designed to decrypt “satellite navigation system” ranging code designed for government use;

subsection.leadIn: Integration “software” as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Integration “software” for the equipment controlled by 7A103(b);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Integration “software” specially designed for the equipment controlled by 7A003 or 7A103(a); (L.N. 132 of 2001)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Integration “software” designed or modified for the equipment controlled by 7A103(c); (L.N. 95 of 2006)
A common form of integration “software” employs Kalman filtering. (L.N. 65 of 2004)

subsection.content: “Software” specially designed for modelling or simulation of the “guidance sets” controlled by 7A117 or for their design integration with the space launch vehicles controlled by 9A004 or sounding rockets controlled by 9A104; (L.N. 183 of 1999; L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 89 of 2021)
“Software” controlled by 7D103 remains controlled when combined with specially designed hardware controlled by 4A102. (L.N. 226 of 2009)
“Software” specially designed or modified for the operation or maintenance of “guidance sets” controlled by 7A117;
7D104 includes “software”, specially designed or modified to enhance the performance of “guidance sets” to achieve or exceed the accuracy controlled by 7A117.

section.name: s0
section.content: Technology

subsection.content: 7E001 includes key management “technology” exclusively for equipment specified in 7A005(a). (L.N. 42 of 2017)
“Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the “production” of equipment controlled by 7A or 7B;
“Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the repair, refurbishing or overhaul of equipment controlled by 7A001 to 7A004;

7E003 does not control maintenance “technology” directly associated with calibration, removal or replacement of damaged or unserviceable LRUs and SRAs of a “civil aircraft” as described in ‘Maintenance Level I’ or ‘Maintenance Level II’. (L.N. 85 of 2023)
See Technical Notes to 7B001.

subsection.leadIn: Other “technology”, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: “Technology” for the “development” or “production” of any of the following: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: Air data systems based on surface static data only, i.e. which dispense with conventional air data probes; (E.R. 6 of 2020)
Three dimensional displays for “aircraft”; (L.N. 161 of 2011)
“Flight control optical sensor array” specially designed for implementing “active flight control systems”;

“Data-Based Referenced Navigation” (“DBRN”) Systems designed to navigate underwater, using sonar or gravity databases, that provide a positioning “accuracy” equal to or less (better) than 0.4 nautical miles; (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: “Development” “technology”, as follows, for “active flight control systems” (including “fly-by-wire systems” or “fly-by-light systems”): (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.content: Photonic-based “technology” for sensing “aircraft” or flight control component state, transferring flight control data, or commanding actuator movement, “required” for “fly-by-light systems” or “active flight control systems”; (L.N. 42 of 2017)
7E004(b)(3) does not control algorithms for off-line maintenance. (L.N. 42 of 2017)
7E004(b)(4) does not control algorithms for the elimination of fault effects through comparison of redundant data sources, or off-line pre-planned responses to anticipated failures. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.leadIn: 7E004(b)(5) does not control:

subparagraph.content: “Technology” for integration of digital flight control, navigation and propulsion control data into a digital flight management system for “flight path optimisation”.
“Technology” for “aircraft” flight instrument systems integrated solely for VOR, DME, ILS or MLS navigation or approaches.

subparagraph.leadIn: “Technology” “required” for deriving the functional requirements for “fly-by-wire systems” having all of the following— (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: that have ‘inner-loop’ airframe stability controls requiring a loop closure rate of 40 Hz or greater;
‘Inner-loop’ refers to functions of “active flight control systems” that automate airframe stability controls.

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.leadIn: that meet any of the following descriptions:

subparagraph.content: Correct an aerodynamically unstable airframe, measured at any point in a design flight envelope, that would lose recoverable control if not corrected within 0.5 seconds;
Combine controls in 2 or more axes while compensating for ‘abnormal changes in aircraft state’;
‘Abnormal changes in aircraft state’ include in-flight structural damage, loss of engine thrust, disabled control surface and destabilizing shifts in cargo load.
Perform the functions specified in 7E004(b)(5);
7E004(b)(7)(b)(3) does not control autopilots.

Enable an “aircraft” to have a stable controlled flight, other than during take-off or landing, at an angle of attack greater than 18 degrees, a side slip at 15 degrees, a pitch rate or yaw rate of 15 degrees per second, or a roll rate of 90 degrees per second; (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.leadIn: “Technology” “required” for deriving the functional requirements for “fly-by-wire systems” to achieve—

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: No loss of control of the “aircraft” in the event of a consecutive sequence of any 2 individual faults within the “fly-by-wire system”; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: A probability of loss of control of the “aircraft” that is less (better) than 1 × 10–9 failures per flight hour; (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.continued: 7E004(b) does not control “technology” associated with common computer elements and utilities (e.g. input signal acquisition, output signal transmission, computer “program” and data loading, built-in test, task scheduling mechanisms) not providing a specific flight control system function. (L.N. 42 of 2017; E.R. 6 of 2020; L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: “Technology” for the “development” of helicopter systems, as follows:

subparagraph.leadIn: Multi-axis fly-by-wire or fly-by-light controllers which combine the functions of at least two of the following into one controlling element:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Collective controls;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Cyclic controls;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Yaw controls;
“Circulation-controlled anti-torque or circulation-controlled directional control systems”;
Rotor blades incorporating ‘variable geometry aerofoils’ for use in systems using individual blade control;
‘Variable geometry aerofoils’ use trailing edge flaps or tabs, or leading edge slats or pivoted nose droop, the position of which can be controlled in flight. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: “Technology” for protection of avionics and electrical sub-systems against electromagnetic pulse (EMP) and electromagnetic interference (EMI) hazards, from external sources, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Design “technology” for shielding systems;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Design “technology” for the configuration of hardened electrical circuits and sub-systems;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Design “technology” for the determination of hardening criteria of 7E102(a) and (b);

subsection.content: “Technology” for the integration of the flight control, guidance, and propulsion data into a flight management system for optimization of rocket system trajectory;

section.name: s0
section.content: Systems, Equipment and Components

subsection.leadIn: Submersible vehicles and surface vessels, as follows:
For the control status of equipment for submersible vehicles, see:
Category 6 for sensors;
Categories 7 and 8 for navigation equipment;
Category 8A for underwater equipment.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Manned, tethered submersible vehicles designed to operate at depths exceeding 1 000 m;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Manned, untethered submersible vehicles, having any of the following:

subparagraph.leadIn: Designed to ‘operate autonomously’ and having a lifting capacity of all of the following: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: 10% or more of their weight in air; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: 15 kN or more;
Designed to operate at depths exceeding 1 000 m; or

subparagraph.leadIn: Having all of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Designed to continuously ‘operate autonomously’ for 10 hours or more;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: ‘Range’ of 25 nautical miles or more; (L.N. 226 of 2009)

For the purpose of 8A001(b), ‘operate autonomously’ means fully submerged, without snorkel, all systems working and cruising at minimum speed at which the submersible vehicle can safely control its depth dynamically by using its depth planes only, with no need for a support vessel or support base on the surface, sea-bed or shore, and containing a propulsion system for submerged or surface use.
For the purposes of 8A001(b), ‘range’ means half the maximum distance a submersible vehicle can ‘operate autonomously’. (L.N. 226 of 2009)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: Unmanned submersible vehicles as follows:

subparagraph.leadIn: Unmanned submersible vehicles having any of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Designed for deciding a course relative to any geographical reference without real time human assistance;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Acoustic data or command link;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Wireless optical data or command link exceeding 1 000 m; (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.leadIn: Unmanned submersible vehicles, not specified in 8A001(c)(1), having all of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Designed to operate with a tether;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Designed to operate at depths exceeding 1 000 m;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.leadIn: Having any of the following:

subparagraph.content: Designed for self-propelled manoeuvre using propulsion motors or thrusters specified in 8A002(a)(2);
Fibre optic data link; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: Ocean salvage systems with a lifting capacity exceeding 5 MN for salvaging objects from depths exceeding 250 m and having any of the following:

subparagraph.content: Dynamic positioning systems capable of position keeping within 20 m of a given point provided by the navigation system; or
Seafloor navigation and navigation integration systems for depths exceeding 1 000 m with positioning “accuracies” to within 10 m of a predetermined point; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: Marine systems, equipment and components, as follows: (L.N. 254 of 2008)
For underwater communications systems, see Category 5, Part 1—Telecommunications. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Systems, equipment and components, specially designed or modified for submersible vehicles and designed to operate at depths exceeding 1 000 m, as follows: (L.N. 254 of 2008)

subparagraph.content: Pressure housings or pressure hulls with a maximum inside chamber diameter exceeding 1.5 m;
Direct current propulsion motors or thrusters;
Umbilical cables, and connectors therefor, using optical fibre and having synthetic strength members;
Components manufactured from material specified in 8C001;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Systems specially designed or modified for the automated control of the motion of submersible vehicles controlled by 8A001 using navigation data, having closed loop servo-controls and having any of the following: (L.N. 132 of 2001; L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.content: Enabling a vehicle to move within 10 m of a predetermined point in the water column;
Maintaining the position of the vehicle within 10 m of a predetermined point in the water column; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
Maintaining the position of the vehicle within 10 m while following a cable on or under the sea-bed;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Fibre optic pressure hull penetrators; (L.N. 89 of 2013)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: Underwater vision systems having all of the following:

subparagraph.content: Specially designed or modified for remote operation with a submersible vehicle; (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.leadIn: Employing any of the following techniques to minimize the effects of back scatter:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Range-gated illuminators;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Range-gated laser systems; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: Light systems, as follows, specially designed or modified for underwater use:

subparagraph.content: Argon arc light systems specially designed for use below 1 000 m;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: “Robots” specially designed for underwater use, controlled by using a dedicated computer, having any of the following: (L.N. 95 of 2006)

subparagraph.content: Systems that control the “robot” using information from sensors which measure force or torque applied to an external object, distance to an external object, or tactile sense between the “robot” and an external object; or

The ability to exert a force of 250 N or more or a torque of 250 Nm or more and using titanium based alloys or “composite” “fibrous or filamentary materials” in their structural members; (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.leadIn: Remotely controlled articulated manipulators specially designed or modified for use with submersible vehicles, having any of the following:

subparagraph.leadIn: Systems which control the manipulator using information from sensors which measure any of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Torque or force applied to an external object;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Tactile sense between the manipulator and an external object; or (L.N. 161 of 2011)
Controlled by proportional master-slave techniques and having 5 degrees of ‘freedom of movement’ or more; (L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 42 of 2017)
Only functions having proportionally related motion control using positional feedback are counted when determining the number of degrees of ‘freedom of movement’. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.leadIn: Air independent power systems, specially designed for underwater use, as follows:

subparagraph.leadIn: Brayton or Rankine cycle engine air independent power systems having any of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: Systems specially designed to use a monoatomic gas;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Devices or enclosures specially designed for underwater noise reduction in frequencies below 10 kHz, or special mounting devices for shock mitigation; or

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.leadIn: Systems specially designed:

subparagraph.content: To pressurise the products of reaction or for fuel reformation;
To store the products of the reaction; and
To discharge the products of the reaction against a pressure of 100 kPa or more;

subparagraph.leadIn: Diesel cycle engine air independent systems, having all of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: Systems specially designed to use a monoatomic gas;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Devices or enclosures specially designed for underwater noise reduction in frequencies below 10 kHz, or special mounting devices for shock mitigation; and

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: Specially designed exhaust systems that do not exhaust continuously the products of combustion;

subparagraph.leadIn: “Fuel cell” air independent power systems with an output exceeding 2 kW having any of the following: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Devices or enclosures specially designed for underwater noise reduction in frequencies below 10 kHz, or special mounting devices for shock mitigation; or

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.leadIn: Systems specially designed:

subparagraph.content: To pressurise the products of reaction or for fuel reformation;
To store the products of the reaction; and
To discharge the products of the reaction against a pressure of 100 kPa or more;

subparagraph.leadIn: Stirling cycle engine air independent power systems, having all of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Devices or enclosures specially designed for underwater noise reduction in frequencies below 10 kHz or special mounting devices for shock mitigation; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Specially designed exhaust systems which discharge the products of combustion against a pressure of 100 kPa or more;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.leadIn: Propellers, power transmission systems, power generation systems, and noise reduction systems and related equipment, as follows: (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.leadIn: Water-screw propeller, power generation systems or transmission systems designed for use on vessels, as follows:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Controllable-pitch propellers and hub assemblies rated at more than 30 MW;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Internally liquid-cooled electric propulsion motors with a power output exceeding 2.5 MW; (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: “Superconductive” propulsion motors, with a power output exceeding 0.1 MW; (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: Power transmission systems, incorporating “composite” shafts and designed to transmit power exceeding 10 MW; (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: Ventilated or base-ventilated propeller systems rated at more than 2.5 MW;

subparagraph.leadIn: Noise reduction systems and related equipment, designed for use on vessels of 1 000 tonnes displacement or more, as follows: (L.N. 6 of 2025)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Systems that attenuate underwater noise at frequencies below 500 Hz and consist of compound acoustic mounts for the acoustic isolation of diesel engines, diesel generator sets, gas turbines, gas turbine generator sets, propulsion motors or propulsion reduction gears, specially designed for sound or vibration isolation, having an intermediate mass exceeding 30% of the equipment to be mounted;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: ‘Active noise reduction or cancellation systems’ incorporate electronic control systems capable of actively reducing equipment vibration by the generation of anti-noise or anti-vibration signals directly to the source. (L.N. 161 of 2011)
Permanent magnet electric propulsion motors specially designed for submersible vehicles, having a power output exceeding 0.1 MW;
8A002(o)(4) includes rim-driven propulsion systems. (L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.leadIn: Pumpjet propulsion systems having all of the following:

subparagraph.content: Power output exceeding 2.5 MW;
Using divergent nozzle and flow conditioning vane techniques to improve propulsive efficiency or reduce propulsion-generated underwater-radiated noise; (L.N. 161 of 2011)

paragraph.name: q
paragraph.leadIn: Underwater swimming and diving equipment as follows:

subparagraph.content: Closed circuit rebreathers;
Semi-closed circuit rebreathers;

paragraph.continued: 8A002(q) does not apply to individual rebreathers for personal use when accompanying their users. (L.N. 161 of 2011)
For equipment and devices specially designed for military use, see the Munitions List. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: r

subparagraph.content: 8A002(r) does not apply to diver deterrent systems based on underwater explosive devices, air guns or combustible sources.
8A002(r) includes diver deterrent acoustic systems that use spark gap sources, also known as plasma sound sources. (L.N. 161 of 2011)

section.name: s0
section.content: Test, Inspection and Production Equipment

subsection.content: Water tunnels designed to have a background noise of less than 100 dB (reference 1 μPa, 1 Hz) within the frequency range exceeding 0 Hz but not exceeding 500 Hz and designed for measuring acoustic fields generated by a hydro-flow around propulsion system models;

section.name: s0
section.content: Materials

subsection.leadIn: ‘Syntactic foam’ designed for underwater use, having all of the following: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Designed for marine depths exceeding 1000 m; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: A density less than 561 kg/m3;

subsection.continued: ‘Syntactic foam’ consists of hollow spheres of plastic or glass embedded in a resin “matrix”. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

section.name: s0
section.content: Software

section.name: s0
section.content: Technology

subsection.content: “Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the “development” or “production” of equipment or materials controlled by 8A, 8B or 8C;

subsection.leadIn: Other “technology”, as follows:

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: “Technology” for the overhaul or refurbishing of equipment controlled by 8A001, 8A002(b), 8A002(j), 8A002(o) or 8A002(p);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: “Technology” according to the General Technology Note for the “development” or “production” of any of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.leadIn: Surface-effect vehicles (fully skirted variety) having all of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: A maximum design speed, fully loaded, exceeding 30 knots in a significant wave height of 1.25 m or more;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: A cushion pressure exceeding 3 830 Pa;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: A light-ship-to-full-load displacement ratio of less than 0.70;

subparagraph.leadIn: ‘Small waterplane area vessels’ having any of the following characteristics:

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: A full load displacement exceeding 1 500 tonnes with a maximum design speed, fully loaded, exceeding 25 knots in a significant wave height of 4 m or more; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subparagraph.continued: A ‘small waterplane area vessel’ is defined by the following formula: waterplane area at an operational design draft that is less than 2 × (displaced volume at the operational design draft)2/3. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

section.name: s0
section.content: Systems, Equipment and Components
(For propulsion systems designed or rated against neutron or transient ionizing radiation, see the Munitions List.)

subsection.leadIn: Aero gas turbine engines having any of the following:
See also 9A101.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Incorporating any of the “technologies” specified by 9E003(a), 9E003(h) or 9E003(i); or (L.N. 161 of 2011; L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.leadIn: 9A001(a) does not control aero gas turbine engines that meet both of the following descriptions:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Certified by the civil aviation authority or authorities of one or more “Participating States”;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.leadIn: Intended to power non-military manned “aircraft” for which any of the following has been issued by the civil aviation authority or authorities of one or more “Participating States” for the “aircraft” with this specific engine type:

subparagraph.content: A civil Type Certificate;
An equivalent document recognized by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

9A001(a) does not control aero gas turbine engines designed for Auxiliary Power Units (APUs) approved by the civil aviation authority or authorities of one or more “Participating States”. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: ‘Marine gas turbine engines’ designed to use liquid fuel and having all of the following, and specially designed assemblies and components of those items:

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: ‘Corrected specific fuel consumption’ not exceeding 0.219 kg/kWh at 35% of the maximum continuous power when using liquid fuel;

subsection.continued: The term ‘marine gas turbine engines’ includes those industrial, or aero-derivative, gas turbine engines adapted for a ship’s electric power generation or propulsion.

For the purposes of 9A002, ‘corrected specific fuel consumption’ is the specific fuel consumption of the engine corrected to a marine distillate liquid fuel having a net specific energy (i.e. net heating value) of 42 MJ/kg (ISO 3977-2 (1997)).

subsection.leadIn: Specially designed assemblies and components, incorporating any of the “technologies” specified by 9E003(a), 9E003(h), 9E003(i) or 9E003(k), for any of the following aero gas turbine engines: (L.N. 183 of 1999; L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Specified by 9A001;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Whose design or production origins are either non-“Participating States” or unknown to the manufacturer; (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: Space launch vehicles, “spacecraft”, “spacecraft buses”, “spacecraft payloads”, “spacecraft” on-board systems or equipment, terrestrial equipment, air-launch platforms and “sub-orbital craft”, as follows: (L.N. 85 of 2023)
See also 9A104.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Space launch vehicles;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: “Spacecraft”;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: “Spacecraft buses”;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: On-board systems or equipment, specially designed for “spacecraft” and having any of the following functions:

subparagraph.content: ‘Command and telemetry data handling’;
For the purposes of 9A004(e)(1), ‘command and telemetry data handling’ includes bus data management, storage and processing.
‘Payload data handling’;
For the purposes of 9A004(e)(2), ‘payload data handling’ includes payload data management, storage and processing.
‘Attitude and orbit control’;
For the purposes of 9A004(e)(3), ‘attitude and orbit control’ includes sensing and actuation to determine and control the position and orientation of a “spacecraft”.
For equipment specially designed for military use, see ML11(c). (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: Terrestrial equipment, specially designed for “spacecraft”, as follows:

subparagraph.leadIn: Telemetry and telecommand equipment specially designed for any of the following data processing functions:

subparagraph.name: a
b
subparagraph.content: Command data processing for formatting command data being sent to the “spacecraft” to control the “spacecraft bus”; (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.leadIn: Simulators specially designed for ‘verification of operational procedures’ of “spacecraft”;

continued.leadIn: For the purposes of 9A004(f)(2), ‘verification of operational procedures’ is any of the following:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Command sequence confirmation;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Operational training;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Operational rehearsals;

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: Operational analysis. (L.N. 89 of 2021)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: “Aircraft” specially designed or modified to be air-launch platforms for space launch vehicles or “sub-orbital craft”; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: “Sub-orbital craft”; (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.content: Liquid rocket propulsion systems containing any of the systems or components controlled by 9A006;
See also 9A105 and 9A119.

subsection.leadIn: Systems and components specially designed for liquid rocket propulsion systems, as follows:
See also 9A106, 9A108 and 9A120. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Cryogenic refrigerators, flightweight dewars, cryogenic heat pipes or cryogenic systems, designed to restrict cryogenic fluid losses to less than 30% per year; (L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Cryogenic containers or closed-cycle refrigeration systems, designed to maintain or produce temperatures less than or equal to 100 K (-173.15°C); (L.N. 6 of 2025)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Slush hydrogen storage or transfer systems;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: High-pressure (exceeding 10.6 MPa) thrust chambers and nozzles therefor;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: Propellant storage systems using the principle of capillary containment or positive expulsion (i.e. with flexible bladders); (E.R. 6 of 2020)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: Liquid propellant injectors, with individual orifices of 0.381 mm or smaller in diameter (an area of 1.14 × 10-3 cm2 or smaller for non-circular orifices) and specially designed for liquid rocket engines; (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.name: h

subsection.leadIn: Solid rocket propulsion systems with any of the following:
See also 9A107 and 9A119. (L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Total impulse capacity exceeding 1.1 MNs;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: Stage mass fractions exceeding 88% and propellant solid loadings exceeding 86%;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Any of the components controlled by 9A008; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: Insulation and propellant bonding systems using direct-bonded motor designs to provide a ‘strong mechanical bond’ or a barrier to chemical migration between the solid propellant and case insulation material;
For the purposes of 9A007(e), a ‘strong mechanical bond’ means bond strength equal to or more than propellant strength.

subsection.leadIn: Components, as follows, specially designed for solid rocket propulsion systems:
See also 9A108.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: For the purpose of 9A008(a), a ‘strong mechanical bond’ means bond strength equal to or more than propellant strength.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Filament-wound “composite” motor cases exceeding 0.61 m in diameter or having ‘structural efficiency ratios (PV/W)’ exceeding 25 km;
The ‘structural efficiency ratio (PV/W)’ is the burst pressure (P) multiplied by the vessel volume (V) divided by the total pressure vessel weight (W). (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Nozzles with thrust levels exceeding 45 kN or nozzle throat erosion rates of less than 0.075 mm/s;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: Movable nozzle or secondary fluid injection thrust vector control systems capable of any of the following:

subparagraph.content: Omni-axial movement exceeding +5°;
Angular vector rotations of 20°/s or more; or
Angular vector accelerations of 40°/s2 or more;

subsection.leadIn: Hybrid rocket propulsion systems with:
See also 9A109 and 9A119.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Total impulse capacity exceeding 1.1 MNs; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Thrust levels exceeding 220 kN in vacuum exit conditions;

subsection.leadIn: Specially designed components, systems and structures for launch vehicles, launch vehicle propulsion systems or “spacecraft”, as follows:
See also 1A002 and 9A110.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Components and structures, each exceeding 10 kg and specially designed for launch vehicles, and manufactured using any of the following: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.leadIn: A metal “matrix” “composite” reinforced by:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Any of the materials specified in 1C007;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Any of the “fibrous or filamentary materials” specified in 1C010; or

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Any of the aluminides specified in 1C002(a);
A ceramic-“matrix” “composite” material specified in 1C007;

paragraph.continued: The weight cut-off is not relevant for nose cones.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Components and structures, specially designed for any of the launch vehicle propulsion systems specified in 9A005 to 9A009, and manufactured using any of the following: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.leadIn: A metal “matrix” “composite” reinforced by:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Any of the materials specified in 1C007;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Any of the “fibrous or filamentary materials” specified in 1C010; or

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: Any of the aluminides specified in 1C002(a);
A ceramic-“matrix” “composite” material specified in 1C007;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: Pulsed liquid rocket engines with thrust-to-weight ratios equal to or more than 1 kN/kg and a ‘response time’ of less than 30 ms; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
For the purposes of 9A010(d), ‘response time’ is the time required to achieve 90% of total rated thrust from start-up. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.content: Ramjet, scramjet or ‘combined cycle engines’ and specially designed components therefor; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
See also 9A111 and 9A118.

content.leadIn: For the purposes of 9A011, ‘combined cycle engines’ combine two or more of the following types of engines:

paragraph.content: Gas turbine engine (turbojet, turboprop and turbofan);
Ramjet or scramjet;

subsection.leadIn: “Unmanned aerial vehicles” (“UAVs”), unmanned “airships”, related equipment and components, as follows: (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.content: See also 9A112.
For “UAVs” that are “sub-orbital craft”, see 9A004(h). (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: “UAVs” or unmanned “airships”, designed to have controlled flights out of the direct ‘natural vision’ of the ‘operator’ and meeting either of the following descriptions: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.leadIn: Meeting both of the following requirements:

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Having a maximum ‘endurance’ that is equal to or greater than 30 minutes but less than 1 hour;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Designed for take-off and having stable controlled flight in wind gusts equal to or exceeding 46.3 km/h (25 knots);
Having a maximum ‘endurance’ of 1 hour or greater;

continued.leadIn: For the purposes of 9A012(a):

subparagraph.content: ‘Operator’ is a person who initiates or commands a “UAV” or unmanned “airship” flight.
‘Endurance’ is to be calculated for ISA conditions (ISO 2533 (1975)) at sea level with zero wind.
‘Natural vision’ means unaided human sight, with or without corrective lenses.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Related equipment and components, as follows: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: Turbojet and turbofan engines, other than those specified in 9A001, as follows: (L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 254 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Engines having all of the following characteristics: (L.N. 89 of 2021)

subparagraph.content: ‘Maximum thrust value’ greater than 400 N excluding civil certified engines with a ‘maximum thrust value’ greater than 8 890 N; (L.N. 65 of 2004; L.N. 89 of 2021; L.N. 85 of 2023)
Specific fuel consumption of 0.15 kg N-1 hr-1 or less; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
‘Dry weight’ less than 750 kg; (L.N. 89 of 2021)
‘First-stage rotor diameter’ less than 1 m; (L.N. 89 of 2021)

For the purposes of 9A101(a)(1), ‘maximum thrust value’ is the manufacturer’s demonstrated maximum thrust for the engine type un-installed at sea level static conditions using the ICAO standard atmosphere. The civil type certified thrust value will be equal to or less than the manufacturer’s demonstrated maximum thrust for the engine type un-installed. (L.N. 85 of 2023)
‘Dry weight’ is the weight of the engine without fluids (fuel, hydraulic fluid, oil, etc.) and does not include the nacelle (housing).
‘First-stage rotor diameter’ is the diameter of the first rotating stage of the engine, whether a fan or compressor, measured at the leading edge of the blade tips. (L.N. 89 of 2021)
Specific fuel consumption is determined at maximum continuous thrust for engine type un-installed at sea level static conditions using the ICAO standard atmosphere. (L.N. 85 of 2023)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Engines designed or modified for use in “missiles” or unmanned aerial vehicles specified in 9A012 or 9A112(a);

subsection.leadIn: ‘Turboprop engine systems’ specially designed for unmanned aerial vehicles specified in 9A012 or 9A112(a), and specially designed components for those systems, having a ‘maximum power’ greater than 10 kW; (L.N. 85 of 2023)
9A102 does not control civil certified engines. (L.N. 42 of 2017)

paragraph.leadIn: For the purposes of 9A102, a ‘turboprop engine system’ incorporates all of the following: (L.N. 42 of 2017)

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: Turboshaft engine;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: Power transmission system to transfer the power to a propeller.

paragraph.content: For the purposes of 9A102, ‘maximum power’ is achieved un-installed at sea level static conditions using the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) standard atmosphere. (L.N. 42 of 2017; L.N. 85 of 2023)

subsection.content: Sounding rockets, capable of a range of at least 300 km;
See also 9A004.

subsection.leadIn: Liquid propellant rocket engines or gel propellant rocket motors, as follows: (L.N. 89 of 2021)
See also 9A119.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Liquid propellant rocket engines or gel propellant rocket motors, usable in “missiles”, other than those specified in 9A005, integrated, or designed or modified to be integrated, into a liquid propellant or gel propellant propulsion system that has a total impulse capacity equal to or greater than 1.1 MNs;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Liquid propellant rocket engines or gel propellant rocket motors, usable in complete rocket systems or unmanned aerial vehicles, capable of a range of 300 km, other than those specified in 9A005 or 9A105(a), integrated, or designed or modified to be integrated, into a liquid propellant or gel propellant propulsion system that has a total impulse capacity equal to or greater than 0.841 MNs; (L.N. 132 of 2001; L.N. 95 of 2006; L.N. 85 of 2023)
